entry.et: Middle English, from Old English gesund; akin to Old High German gisunt healthy

def.dt: :free from error, fallacy, or misapprehension sound reasoning
:exhibiting or based on thorough knowledge and experience sound scholarship
:showing good judgment or sense sound advice

entry.et: Middle English soun, from Anglo-French son, sun, from Latin sonus, from sonare to sound; akin to Old English swinn melody, Sanskrit svanati it sounds

def.dt: :the sensation perceived by the sense of hearing
:mechanical radiant energy that is transmitted by longitudinal pressure waves in a material medium (as air) and is the objective cause of hearing
:value in terms of speech sounds -cher of teacher and -ture of creature have the same sound
:hearing distance :earshot within sound of your voice
:a particular musical style characteristic of an individual, a group, or an area the Nashville sound
:to cause to sound sound a trumpet
:to order, signal, or indicate by a sound sound the alarm
:to examine by causing to emit sounds sound the lungs
:to convey the impression of :sound like that sounds a logical use of resources Economist
:to give a summons by sound the bugle sounds to battle
:to make or convey an impression especially when heard it sounds good to me you sound just like your mother

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English sund swimming, sea & Old Norse sund swimming, strait; akin to Old English swimman to swim

def.dt: :a long broad inlet of the ocean generally parallel to the coast
:a long passage of water connecting two larger bodies (as a sea with the ocean) or separating a mainland and an island

entry.et: Middle English, from Middle French sonder, from Old French *sonde sounding line, probably from Old English or Middle English sund- (as in Old English sundlīne sounding line) from sund sea

def.dt: :to try to find out the views or intentions of :probe often used with out
:to explore or examine (a body cavity) with a sound
:to ascertain the depth of water especially with a sounding line
:to look into or investigate the possibility sent commissioners … to sound for peace Thomas Jefferson
:to dive down suddenly used of a fish or whale

entry.et: French sonde, from Middle French, literally, sounding line

def.dt: :an elongated instrument for exploring or sounding body cavities
:a sudden large increase in aerodynamic drag that occurs as the speed of an aircraft approaches the speed of sound
:a brief recorded statement (as by a public figure) broadcast especially on a television news program
